content.title: Inhalation Injury
content.summary: Inhalation injury encompasses thermal injury to the upper airway, chemical injury to the tracheobronchial tree and alveoli from inhaled toxins, and systemic toxicity from carbon monoxide and cyanide. It significantly increases mortality in burn patients and requires early recognition, airway protection, and supportive care.
key_points: Thermal injury confined to supraglottic airway (heat dissipates rapidly); steam can injure lower airways
Chemical injury from combustion products (aldehydes, acids, particulates) causes tracheobronchitis and ARDS
Carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning: cherry-red color unreliable; treat with 100% O2 or hyperbaric oxygen
Cyanide toxicity: metabolic acidosis with normal PaO2; treat with hydroxocobalamin
Early intubation if clinical suspicion (facial burns, singed nasal hairs, carbonaceous sputum, stridor)
Bronchoscopy confirms diagnosis; management is primarily supportive with aggressive pulmonary toilet
content.statement: Inhalation injury is a heterogeneous condition ranging from supraglottic thermal burns to systemic toxicity from inhaled gases. Early airway management and recognition of systemic poisoning are critical, as inhalation injury significantly increases mortality in burn patients.

explanation.intuition: The upper airway is an effective heat exchanger, limiting thermal injury to supraglottic structures. However, steam and toxic chemicals in smoke bypass this protection. Combustion products cause direct epithelial damage, inflammation, and impaired mucociliary clearance. CO binds hemoglobin with 200× affinity of oxygen, and cyanide blocks mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase.
explanation.key_insight: The triad of facial burns, carbonaceous sputum, and enclosed-space fire exposure should prompt early intubation before airway edema progresses. CO-oximetry (not standard pulse oximetry) is required to detect carboxyhemoglobin, as SpO2 is falsely normal in CO poisoning.
explanation.technical_details: Diagnosis: flexible bronchoscopy showing erythema, edema, carbonaceous deposits, mucosal sloughing. CO poisoning: COHb >10% (smokers >15%) with symptoms. Cyanide: lactate >10 mmol/L with unexplained acidosis in fire victim. Treatment: 100% O2 until COHb <5%; hydroxocobalamin 5g IV for cyanide.

definitions_glossary.inhalation_injury: Damage to respiratory tract from inhaled heat, toxic gases, or particulate matter from fire/smoke
definitions_glossary.supraglottic_thermal_injury: Heat-induced upper airway edema and burns above vocal cords; can cause rapid airway obstruction
definitions_glossary.chemical_tracheobronchitis: Inflammation of conducting airways from inhaled irritants (aldehydes, acids, ammonia)
definitions_glossary.carbon_monoxide_poisoning: CO binding to hemoglobin with 200-250× oxygen affinity causing tissue hypoxia despite normal PaO2
definitions_glossary.carboxyhemoglobin: COHb: hemoglobin bound to CO; measured by CO-oximetry; normal <3% (smokers <10%)
definitions_glossary.cyanide_poisoning: CN inhibits cytochrome oxidase, blocking cellular respiration; causes lactic acidosis
definitions_glossary.hydroxocobalamin: Vitamin B12 precursor that binds cyanide to form cyanocobalamin; first-line cyanide antidote
definitions_glossary.hyperbaric_oxygen_therapy: HBO at 2-3 ATA accelerates CO elimination and may reduce neurologic sequelae
definitions_glossary.carbonaceous_sputum: Black, sooty sputum indicating smoke inhalation; marker for inhalation injury
definitions_glossary.mucociliary_dysfunction: Impaired airway clearance from epithelial injury; increases infection risk
definitions_glossary.smoke_inhalation: Inhalation of combustion products including gases, vapors, and particulate matter
definitions_glossary.airway_edema: Swelling of upper airway tissues; may progress rapidly requiring emergent intubation

pathophysiology.mechanism: Three distinct injury patterns: (1) Thermal injury to supraglottic structures causes edema that can progress to complete obstruction within 12-24 hours. (2) Chemical injury from inhaled irritants causes epithelial necrosis, inflammation, bronchorrhea, and impaired mucociliary clearance leading to atelectasis and pneumonia. (3) Systemic toxicity from CO (blocks O2 delivery) and cyanide (blocks O2 utilization) causes cellular hypoxia.
key_pathways: Heat → upper airway burns → progressive edema → airway obstruction
Toxic gases → epithelial injury → inflammation → bronchorrhea → atelectasis/pneumonia
CO → COHb formation → decreased O2-carrying capacity → tissue hypoxia
CN → cytochrome oxidase inhibition → blocked oxidative phosphorylation → lactic acidosis
pathophysiology.clinical_significance: Inhalation injury increases mortality in burns by 20% and is the leading cause of death in fire victims. The combination of inhalation injury with cutaneous burns synergistically increases mortality.

diagnostic_studies.co_oximetry: COHb level; pulse oximetry is falsely normal in CO poisoning
diagnostic_studies.arterial_blood_gas: Metabolic acidosis suggests systemic toxicity; PaO2 may be normal
diagnostic_studies.lactate: Elevated (>10 mmol/L in fire victim) suggests cyanide poisoning
diagnostic_studies.bronchoscopy: Gold standard; shows erythema, edema, carbonaceous deposits, mucosal necrosis

severity_classification.mild: Erythema, edema of upper airway; no significant lower airway injury
severity_classification.moderate: Tracheobronchitis with carbonaceous deposits; no significant alveolar injury
severity_classification.severe: Extensive mucosal sloughing, lower airway involvement, parenchymal injury

airway_management.timing: Intubate early; progressive edema can make later intubation impossible
airway_management.technique: Larger ETT (7.5-8.0+) to allow bronchoscopy; avoid nasotracheal in facial burns

carbon_monoxide.immediate: 100% FiO2 via non-rebreather or mechanical ventilation
carbon_monoxide.half_life: CO elimination: 320 min on room air → 80 min on 100% O2 → 23 min with HBO

cyanide.clinical_suspicion: Fire victim with lactic acidosis, altered consciousness, unexplained cardiovascular collapse
cyanide.hydroxocobalamin: 5g IV over 15 min; may repeat once; preferred over cyanide kit

supportive_care.bronchoscopy: Therapeutic bronchoscopy to remove debris and casts
supportive_care.fluid_management: Conservative after initial resuscitation to avoid pulmonary edema

skos.definition: Injury to the respiratory tract from inhaled heat, toxic chemicals, or particulate matter from fire or industrial exposure, encompassing upper airway thermal injury, chemical tracheobronchitis, and systemic toxicity

icd10.display: Toxic effect of unspecified gases, fumes and vapors

learning_objectives: Recognize clinical indicators of inhalation injury requiring early airway protection
Explain the pathophysiology of thermal vs chemical vs systemic inhalation injury
Diagnose and treat carbon monoxide poisoning using CO-oximetry and 100% oxygen
Identify cyanide toxicity in fire victims and administer appropriate antidote
Apply bronchoscopy findings to grade inhalation injury severity
clinical_pearls: Pulse oximetry is falsely normal in CO poisoning - must use CO-oximetry
Cherry-red skin color is unreliable and usually post-mortem finding
Intubate early if any signs of upper airway involvement - edema progresses rapidly
Thermal injury usually above glottis; steam and toxins injure lower airways
Lactate >10 + unexplained acidosis in fire victim = suspect cyanide
HBO indications: LOC, neuro symptoms, cardiac ischemia, pregnancy, COHb >25%
common_misconceptions: Pulse oximetry detects CO poisoning (SpO2 is falsely normal; need CO-oximetry)
Cherry-red color is reliable sign of CO poisoning (rare and usually postmortem)
Thermal injury affects lower airways (heat dissipates; lower injury is chemical)
